Kenji Honda | designer=Yuji Horii | artist=[[Akira Toriyama]] | writer=Yuji Horii | composer=[[Koichi Sugiyama]] | series=''[[Dragon Quest Monsters]]'' | platforms=[[Game Boy Color]], [[mobile phone]]s, [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]], [[Nintendo 3DS]], [[iOS]]/[[Android (operating_system)|Android]] | released='''Game Boy'''
{{vgrelease|JP|September 25, 1998|NA|January 25, 2000|EU|January 28, 2000}}'''PlayStation'''
{{vgrelease|JP|May 30, 2002}}'''Nintendo 3DS'''
{{vgrelease|JP|May 31, 2012}}'''iOS/Android'''
{{vgrelease|JP|Nov 7, 2018}} | genre=[[Role-playing video game|Role-playing]] | modes=[[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Dragon Warrior Monsters'''''{{efn|Originally released in Japan as {{nihongo|'''''Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry no Wonderland'''''|ドラゴンクエストモンスターズ テリーのワンダーランド|lit. Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry's Wonderland}}}} is the first [[video game]] in the ''[[Dragon Quest Monsters]]'' series. It was released in Japan by [[Enix]] on September 25, 1998, and co-published by [[Eidos Interactive]] in Europe and North America in 2000. It was the first ''[[Dragon Quest]]'' game to be released in Europe. It was released for the [[Game Boy Color]] before the console itself was released; however, the [[ROM cartridge|cartridge]] is backward compatible with the older [[Game Boy]] console in [[black-and-white]] color. The game was remade for the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] in a compilation '''''Dragon Quest Monsters 1+2 Hoshi Furi no Yūsha to Bokujō no Nakamatachi'''''.{{efn|{{nihongo|'''''Dragon Quest Monsters 1+2 Hoshi Furi no Yūsha to Bokujō no Nakamatachi'''''|ドラゴンクエストモンスターズ1・2 星降りの勇者と牧場の仲間たち|}}}} A mobile phone incarnation titled ''Dragon Quest Monsters i'' was released in Japan on January 28, 2002.{{cite web | author=Weiss, Justin | date=January 30, 2002 | title=Dragon Quest Monsters Hits Cell Phones | url=http://www.rpgamer.com/news/Q1-2002/013002c.html | work=RPGamer.com | accessdate=2008-12-13 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525104326/http://www.rpgamer.com/news/Q1-2002/013002c.html | archivedate=May 25, 2011 | df= }} The game features the characters Terry and Milly from ''[[Dragon Quest VI: Realms of Reverie|Dragon Quest VI]]'' when they were children, before the events in ''Dragon Quest VI''. ''Dragon Warrior Monsters'' is often compared to the ''[[Pokémon]]'' series due to their similar gameplay.{{cite web | author=Jeff Gertsmann | year=2004 | title=Dragon Warrior Monsters review | url=http://www.gamespot.com/gbc/rpg/dragonwarriormonsters/review.html | work= | accessdate=2007-10-07 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516113202/http://www.gamespot.com/gbc/rpg/dragonwarriormonsters/review.html | archivedate=2008-05-16 | df= }} Critics set the games apart by noting the in-depth breeding system seen in this game. In May 2012, a remake of the game for the [[Nintendo 3DS]], titled '''''Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry no Wonderland 3D''''',{{efn|{{nihongo|'''''Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry no Wonderland 3D'''''|ドラゴンクエストモンスターズ テリーのワンダーランド3D|lit. Dragon Quest Monsters Terry's Wonderland 3D}}}} was released.{{cite web |title=Square-Enix Revamping Original Dragon Quest Monsters for 3DS |url=http://www.3dsbuzz.com/square-enix-revamping-original-dragon-quest-monsters-for-3ds |accessdate=2011-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924032143/http://www.3dsbuzz.com/square-enix-revamping-original-dragon-quest-monsters-for-3ds/ |archivedate=2011-09-24 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.siliconera.com/2011/09/18/the-very-first-dragon-quest-monsters-is-being-remade-for-nintendo-3ds/ |title=The Very First Dragon Quest Monsters Is Being Remade For Nintendo 3DS |author=Ishaan |date=September 18, 2011 |work= |publisher=Siliconera |accessdate=September 18, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923094513/http://www.siliconera.com/2011/09/18/the-very-first-dragon-quest-monsters-is-being-remade-for-nintendo-3ds/ |archivedate=September 23, 2011 |df= }} Later in November 2018, the remake was released for smartphoneshttps://gematsu.com/2018/11/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-sp-announced-for-smartphones == Gameplay == The game follows Terry as he attempts to save his sister. Instead of fighting in battle, Terry is able to recruit monsters into his party. When fighting [[Random encounter|random battles]], Terry can set out meat, which may coax the monster into joining the party at the end of the battle. Terry can also breed two monsters, combining them into a new, stronger monster. Excess monsters can be placed on the Farm, a storage place for monsters. They can be picked up or dropped off and there is an option to put monsters at the farm to sleep, which allows them to maintain their wilderness level, but not grow in level. There can be 19 awake and 19 asleep monsters at any one time. A monster's wilderness level lowers as Terry trains them, which makes them more likely to participate in battle. By leaving monsters at the farm awake, they become more wild. Just like in most RPGs, monsters are able to gain [[experience points]] and level up after battles. Each monsters' requirements for experience points to level up varies, depending on their plus number or even what monster family they belong to. When they level up, they gain stats and sometimes skills. All monsters can carry a maximum of eight skills; if a monster can gain more than eight skills you have the option of replacing old skills with new ones. The player moves around to other worlds through warp gates which are located underneath the throne room. To access these gates, the player needs to defeat a certain class ranking. There are a certain number of areas in a world and at the last one, the player needs to defeat a boss. Some bosses in the game offer to join the player's party automatically, some have to be won over with meat, and some will not join at all. Other gates are hidden throughout Great Tree, such as one in the library that is only accessible after befriending over 100 different monsters. In this game the player fights in the arena and goes through ranks that consists of three different battles that must be won before the player can advance to the next ranking. Each rank provides harder challenges: the higher the rank, the harder the monsters. The battles you able to start at are from Rank G and go to Rank D and later in the game you are able to go from Rank C to Rank A and then Rank S. These battles open up gates for the character to explore and are necessary to progress through the story. Tiny Medals are scattered throughout different worlds randomly and are picked up by the player. In the game, there is a man who collects these medals, who is later revealed to be the king of Great Tree, and will give certain monster eggs for how many the player gives to him. Also, Foreign Masters may appear while in other worlds. These encounters with other trainers can result in battle. There are different types of trainers that will give or do something for the player if they are defeated. These trainers monsters may also join you if you give them meat. The game also comes compatible with the PlayStation's [[i-mode]] adaptor, allowing players to upload monsters from the game onto the mobile phone version of ''Dragon Quest Monsters''.{{cite web | last=Henninger | first=Michael | date=2002-01-19 | title=Enix to Port Dragon Quest Monsters Collection to PSone | url=http://www.rpgamer.com/news/Q1-2002/011902a.html | work=RPGamer.com | accessdate=2008-12-13 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015181420/http://www.rpgamer.com/news/Q1-2002/011902a.html | archivedate=2008-10-15 | df= }} === Breeding === After beating Class F in the Arena, the player can breed monsters if they are at level 10 or above at the Shrine of Starry Night, which is taken care of by the current Master Monster Tamer. Breeding requires one male and one female monster. The result of the breeding will be an egg, containing a level 1 monster which has characteristics of both parents, including skills and stats. The egg can then be left in the monster farm or hatched, which costs a small fee. The monster born will have a plus number next to it, the number generally signifying the greatness of the monster's stats, the higher being the better. It costs more money to hatch a monster with a higher plus number than one with no plus number. Also, the number beside the plus multiplied by two is added to the limit for the maximum level for the monster. Once the Egg Evaluator is available for use, eggs can have the gender of the monster they're containing checked and changed. Both requires a small fee which is paid to the Egg Evaluator. The fee increases depending on the monster's plus number. A monster that was created through breeding has much higher stats and many more abilities than a monster that was found in the wild, thus it is much harder to complete the game without breeding many generations. Breeding is also the only way to acquire certain monsters. Also, the monsters that bred to make the egg leave you. == Story == In the days before ''[[Dragon Quest VI: Realms of Reverie|Dragon Quest VI]]'', when Terry and Milly were just children, a strange monster appeared one night and snatched Milly away. Soon after, another monster, similar to the kidnapper, appeared and told Terry his sister was kidnapped by the evil Warubou. He informs Terry that his name is Watabou and must accompany him to the Kingdom of GreatTree. After his arrival, Terry met the King and received Slib the [[Slime (Dragon Quest)|slime]], his first monster to train. If Terry wins the Monster Trainer's Starry Night Tournament, he will be granted a wish.{{cite web | author=Keplek, Patrick | date=March 8, 2000 | title=Dragon Warrior Monsters Review | url=http://www.gaming-age.com/cgi-bin/reviews/review.pl?sys=gameboy&game=dwm | work=Gaming-Age.com | accessdate=2009-10-14 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BpPvQnBY?url=http://www.gaming-age.com/404.html | archivedate=October 31, 2012 | df= }} So Terry sets out with his team to explore the many monster dungeons to win the tournament and rescue his sister. == Nintendo 3DS remake == The Nintendo 3DS remake was announced in September 2011 by publisher [[Square Enix]], and was said to include new monsters, a new story, and additional monsters from ''[[Dragon Quest Monsters: Joker 2]] Professional''. The game was shown as a playable demo at Jump Magazines Jump Festa in December 2011. The game features include shifting from day to night, randomized dungeon layouts, combat with four opponents on each side, and a total of 609 monsters, including all the monsters from the original [[Game Boy Color]] release.{{cite web| title=Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry’s Wonderland 3D Will Have 500 Monsters| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2011/12/12/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-will-have-500-monsters/| author=Ishaan| date=December 12, 2011| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718231121/http://www.siliconera.com/2011/12/12/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-will-have-500-monsters/| archivedate=July 18, 2012| df=}}{{cite web| title=Here’s Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry’s Wonderland 3D’s Special Nintendo 3DS| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/02/28/heres-dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3ds-special-nintendo-3ds/| author=Ishaan| date=February 28, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720032419/http://www.siliconera.com/2012/02/28/heres-dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3ds-special-nintendo-3ds/| archivedate=July 20, 2012| df=}} The game also features an in-game Wi-Fi Store in the bazaar area. The Wi-Fi Store purchases can be made with the in-game currency, gold. The store's items changes daily, and the Wi-Fi item store is only open after doing that day's Wi-Fi Ranking Battle. It can be used to buy monster eggs, (white, silver, and rainbow eggs) skill books, consumable items, and some weapons.{{cite web| title=Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry’s Wonderland 3D Has An Online Store Too| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/05/14/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-has-an-online-store-too/| author=Spencer| date=May 14, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818031239/http://www.siliconera.com/2012/05/14/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-has-an-online-store-too/| archivedate=August 18, 2012| df=}} Players have the ability to import monsters they have raised from ''[[Dragon Quest Monsters: Joker 2]]'' and ''[[Dragon Quest Monsters: Joker 2]] Professional'' (Rank A and higher only) through a free app upon completion of the game.{{cite web| title=Transfer That Dark Slime From Dragon Quest Monsters: Joker 2 Into Terry’s Wonderland 3D| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/05/02/transfer-that-dark-slime-from-dragon-quest-monsters-joker-2-into-terrys-wonderland-3d/| author=Spencer| date=May 2, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120522142134/http://www.siliconera.com/2012/05/02/transfer-that-dark-slime-from-dragon-quest-monsters-joker-2-into-terrys-wonderland-3d/| archivedate=May 22, 2012| df=}} At that point, players can access "Ultimate Combination", where new abilities become available for the players monsters, and the ability to create "super monsters" is possible. X and XY monsters (+, and +* in the original Japanese version) in Joker 2/Professional could be obtained by synthesizing 2 of the same monsters, level 20 for X, and level 50 for XY monsters. However, the method to create them is different in Terry's Wonderland 3D. Both duplicate monsters of different gender have to have their monster's rank points +25 for + monsters, and +50 for +* monsters. In Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry's Wonderland 3D, there is a +, and +* for every monster, while in Joker 2/Professional not every monster had them. After synthesizing a few of these monsters, a new synth will happen immediately afterwards, making a demon book monster that knows said monsters skills. There are more than a few kinds of demon book monsters ranging from small size to large size monsters. Using the [[StreetPass]] feature of the [[Nintendo 3DS]], players can fight other players and attempt to steal their monsters. [[Mii]]s are also utilized in the game, allowing players to customize their character's clothing. Online play is supported, including "Grand Prix" mode for a maximum of eight players.{{cite web| title=Through StreetPass, You Can Steal A Friend’s Dragon Quest Monster| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/03/28/through-streetpass-you-can-steal-a-friends-dragon-quest-monster/| author=Spencer| date=March 28, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721034157/http://www.siliconera.com/2012/03/28/through-streetpass-you-can-steal-a-friends-dragon-quest-monster/| archivedate=July 21, 2012| df=}} In B3 of the Great Tree, one of the two gates there takes you to an arena where you can battle the top 3 users who've won that day's ranking battle. You can do auto commands, AI battle tactics, and use items. The users are AIs, and their data are recorded from said day's ranking battle. You get both bonus points (for Wi-Fi Ranking Battle) and gold. The other gate there takes you to a 100 battle survival course. After 50 battles, it auto saves. If you lose between 51-100, you get to start back at battle 50. These battles can only be done once every 24 hours. == Reception == {{Video game reviews | title = Reviews | EGM = 7.62 out of 10{{cite web| author=| date=| title=Dragon Warrior Monsters Reviews| url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gbc/197155-dragon-warrior-monsters/articles.html| work=Gamerankings.com| accessdate=2009-10-14| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BpPx0dk7?url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gbc/197155-dragon-warrior-monsters/articles.html| archivedate=2012-10-31| df=}} | GI = 8 out of 10 | GSpot = 8.7 out of 10 | IGN = 9 out of 10{{cite web | author=Harris, Craig | date=January 26, 2000 | title=Dragon Warrior Monsters | url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/162/162825p1.html | work=IGN.com | accessdate=2009-10-14 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cqpqc3YL?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/01/27/dragon-warrior-monsters-review | archivedate=December 12, 2012 | df= }} | NP = 7.2 out of 10 | GR = 79.81 out of 100 }} In Japan, ''Dragon Warrior Monsters'' sold 2.35 million copies, of which 1.22 million were sold during 1998—making it the fourth-highest selling game of the year.{{cite web |url=http://chartget.com/2008/07/dragon-quest-sales-history_31.html |title=Dragon Quest Sales History |publisher=Chart Get |accessdate=2009-02-07 |date=2008-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CqprtfhC?url=http://chartget.com/2008/07/dragon-quest-sales-history_31.html |archivedate=2012-12-12 |df= }}{{Cite book |title=Famitsū Gēmu Hakusho 1999 |publisher=[[Enterbrain]] |year=1999 |location=Tokyo |language=Japanese |script-title=ja:ファミ通ゲーム白書1999 |trans-title=Famitsu Game Whitebook 1999 |chapter=1998年ゲームソフト年間売上TOP100 |trans-chapter=1998 Game Software Annual Sales Top 100 |url=http://geimin.net/da/db/1998_ne_fa/index.php |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150807132243/http://geimin.net/da/db/1998_ne_fa/index.php |archivedate=2015-08-07 |df= }} The North American version sold 60,000 copies by April 2000.{{cite web | author=Stahn Mahn | date=April 3, 2000 | title=Sakura Con 2000 Enix Report | url=http://www.rpgfan.com/news/2000/1221.html | work=RPGFan.com | accessdate=2009-01-11 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CqpsV8AR?url=http://www.rpgfan.com/news/2000/1221.html | archivedate=December 12, 2012 | df= }} ''Dragon Warrior Monsters'' received mostly positive reviews, receiving an average score of 78.9% from [[GameRankings]] based on 12 reviews. The game was compared to ''[[Pokémon]]'' by critics because of its similar gameplay, many telling fans to play the game as a means of waiting for the release of [[Pokémon Gold and Silver|''Pokémon Gold'' and ''Silver'']]. GameSpot.com praised the game's visuals, music, and gameplay, stating that the game "may not have the cutesy, over-merchandised appeal of Pokémon, but the rock-solid gameplay makes it a worthwhile endeavor." IGN stated that ''Dragon Warrior Monsters'' features many of ''Pokémon's'' mechanics, "but better," commenting on the game's large cast of monsters and battles. However, IGN also made a distinction between the two games, saying that ''Pokémon's'' ability to capture any wild Pokémon with a Poké Ball as opposed to taming monsters was a better idea. RPGFan.com reviewed the game, mentioning that the game's 215 monsters gave the game a large amount of depth, and that the "bulk and the most fun aspect of the game is catching monsters and breeding them to get more powerful monsters."{{cite web| author=| title=RPGFan Reviews: Dragon Warrior Monsters Reviews| url=http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/dragonwarriormonsters/Dragon_Warrior_Monsters.html| work=RPGFan.com| accessdate=2009-01-11| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CqptVlsM?url=http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/dragonwarriormonsters/Dragon_Warrior_Monsters.html| archivedate=2012-12-12| df=}} Gaming-Age.com similarly pointed out that the breeding aspect of ''Dragon Warrior Monsters'' set it apart from other monster-catching games, noting that its monsters "don't quite have the extra 'omph' that the {{sic|Poke|mon}} creatures do", but that "none of the creatures are so super cutesy that they begin to get on your nerves." PlayStation compilation ''Dragon Quest Monsters 1+2'' received a 33 out of 40 by ''[[Famitsu]]'' magazine.''プレイステーション - ドラゴンクエストモンスターズ1・2 星降りの勇者と牧場の仲間たち''. Weekly Famitsu. No.915 Pt.2. Pg.18. 30 June 2006. The game was the 38th best-selling game of 2002 with 292,275 copies.{{cite web | title=2002 Top 50 Japanese Console Game Chart | url=http://the-magicbox.com/Chart-BestSell2002.shtml | work=The-MagicBox.com | accessdate=2008-12-15 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228060318/http://www.the-magicbox.com/Chart-BestSell2002.shtml | archivedate=2008-12-28 | df= }} The Nintendo 3DS remake has been sold 513,000 copies in the first week.{{cite web| title=Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry’s Wonderland 3D Could Have Sold Even More| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/06/08/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-could-have-sold-even-more/| author=Ishaan| date=June 8, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120811171420/http://www.siliconera.com/2012/06/08/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-could-have-sold-even-more/| archivedate=August 11, 2012| df=}} Publisher [[Square Enix]] sold through 93.96 percent of their stock and several stores sold out of product. A special version of the [[Nintendo 3DS]] bundled with the game also sold 100,000 units in the first week.{{cite web| title=Dragon Quest Monsters: Terry's Wonderland 3D Dominates Japanese Charts| publisher=GameTrailers.com| url=http://www.gametrailers.com/side-mission/17167/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-dominates-japanese-charts| author=Rocco DeMaro| date=June 11, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224122342/http://www.gametrailers.com/side-mission/17167/dragon-quest-monsters-terrys-wonderland-3d-dominates-japanese-charts| archivedate=December 24, 2013| df=}} As of January 2013, the game has 920,000 copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2013-01-28-pokemon-tops-2012-software-charts-in-japan|title=Pokemon tops 2012 software chart in Japan|last=Handrahan|first=Matthew|date=28 January 2013|work=[[GamesIndustry]]|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=21 April 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130411074224/http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2013-01-28-pokemon-tops-2012-software-charts-in-japan|archivedate=11 April 2013|df=}} As a promotion, fast food franchise [[McDonald's]] gave away a Slanin Purple on May 31, 2012 in [[Happy Meals]] to those who had copies of the game, and on June 9 they gave away Lamia, a monster from ''[[Dragon Warrior III]]''. The promotion ended June 21, 2012.{{cite web| title=I’ll Take A Side Of Fries And A Legendary Dragon Quest Monster. To Go, Please.| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/05/08/ill-take-a-side-of-fries-and-a-legendary-dragon-quest-monster-to-go-please/| author=Spencer| date=May 8, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720234518/http://www.siliconera.com/2012/05/08/ill-take-a-side-of-fries-and-a-legendary-dragon-quest-monster-to-go-please/| archivedate=July 20, 2012| df=}} Convenience stores and other establishments in Japan also gave away monsters, including a dimension traveling dragon, a Gold Killing Machine, and Tyranoosaura Wrecks from ''[[Dragon Quest IX: Sentinels of the Starry Skies|Dragon Quest IX]]''.{{cite web| title=I’ll Take One Hot Dog And One Legendary Dragon Quest Dragon. To Go, Please.| publisher=Siliconera| url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/08/01/ill-take-one-hot-dog-and-one-legendary-dragon-quest-dragon-to-go-please/| author=Spencer| date=August 1, 2012| accessdate=August 3, 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121201230708/http://www.siliconera.com/2012/08/01/ill-take-one-hot-dog-and-one-legendary-dragon-quest-dragon-to-go-please/| archivedate=December 1, 2012| df=}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20020805174139/http://www.enix.co.jp/game/dqm/ Official site] {{ja icon}} (via [[Internet Archive]]) * {{MobyGames|id=/dragon-warrior-monsters|name=''Dragon Warrior Monsters''}} {{Dragon Quest series}} [[Category:Role-playing video games]] [[Category:Game Boy Color games]] [[Category:Mobile games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS eShop games]] [[Category:Nintendo Network games]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games]] [[Category:Tose (company) games]] [[Category:Video game prequels]] [[Category:Dragon Quest video games|Dragon Quest Monsters 1]] [[Category:1998 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games scored by Koichi Sugiyama]] [[Category:Video games using procedural generation]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2010}} The '''Edmonton Investors Group Limited Partnership''' ('''EIGLP''') was the [[limited partnership]] that owned the [[Edmonton Oilers]] of the [[National Hockey League]] and the [[Edmonton Oil Kings]] of the [[Western Hockey League]]. With more than thirty individual shareholders, EIGLP was the largest ownership group in the NHL. Among the four [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|North American major sports leagues]], only the [[Green Bay Packers Foundation|Green Bay Packers]] have a larger ownership group.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} The EIG were the key players for keeping the [[Edmonton Oilers]] in [[Edmonton|Edmonton, Alberta]], Canada long term by purchasing the team from then-owner [[Peter Pocklington]] for {{dollarsign|CAD}}107 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|107000000|1998}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} Canadian dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}) and preventing the team by being purchasing the team for US$90 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|90000000|1998}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} American dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) or C$127 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|127000000|1998}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} Canadian dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}). ==History== ===Pre Edmonton Investors Group=== In the mid-1990s, [[Edmonton Oilers]] owner [[Peter Pocklington]] was in a precarious financial situation. Pocklington's main creditor, the [[Alberta Treasury Branches]], were demanding repayment of millions of dollars' worth of loans that ATB had made to Pocklington in the 1980s and early 1990s. The once-popular Pocklington had a strained relationship with Edmontonians due in part to his decision to trade [[Wayne Gretzky]] as well as [[Peter Pocklington#Business Controversy|his other business and political dealings]]. As a result, attendance at [[Northlands Coliseum]] had declined – partly due to the team's declining on-ice fortunes but also due to personal animosity towards the owner. This animosity hindered a 1996 [[season ticket]] drive that was needed to keep the team in Edmonton. It was largely due to the perseverance of future EIG partner [[Cal Nichols]], that the ''Friends of the Oilers'' ticket drive ultimately expanded the season ticket base from a dismal 6,200 to over 13,400, enough to secure the team's future for the short term. However, it was increasingly obvious that Pocklington would not be around for the long term. In early 1997, Pocklington announced his intention to sell up to 45% of the team on the [[stock market]]. Pressure from ATB forced him to abandon this plan and put the team up for sale. When the Oilers were put up for sale, many doubted whether a local ownership could be found and believed the proud franchise would be re-located to an American city as had happened with the teams in [[Quebec Nordiques|Quebec City]] in 1995 and [[Winnipeg Jets (1972–96)|Winnipeg]] in 1996. In 1997, the population of the [[Edmonton Capital Region|Edmonton metropolitan area]] was still under one million, a figure viewed by many fans to be the minimum base a North American major sports team needs to be financially viable. With the only other former [[World Hockey Association]] team in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] re-locating in 1997, many analysts predicted that the "[[domino effect]]" would be completed in 1998 with the Oilers' move. However, the terms of Pocklington's [[lease]] at what was then known as the Edmonton Coliseum prevented him from unilaterally moving the team or selling it to someone who intended to move it. It stipulated that an ownership group willing to keep the team in Edmonton would have six weeks from the time any such intention was declared to purchase the team for US$70 million. In addition, the ATB is a [[crown corporation]] owned by the [[Alberta government]], though they treated the matter as non-political. While [[Alberta Premier]] [[Ralph Klein]] wanted to keep the Oilers in the capital, he was wary of a series of [[scandal]]s involving favouritism at the ATB that had plagued his predecessor, [[Don Getty]], in the 1980s. Klein was unwilling to make any move that might have been perceived by voters as government subsidization of a hockey club that paid multimillion-dollar salaries. However, when Klein's hometown [[Calgary Flames]] encountered financial difficulties in 2000, he immediately moved to assist them by creating a province-wide lottery. ===Cal Nichols looks for investors=== Nichols, a prominent businessman in his own right, immediately began putting together an ownership group. At the time, the Albertan economy—driven by the [[oilpatch]]—was still recovering from price crashes in the 1980s and 1990s. Most Albertan investors preferred to commit their money to the re-emerging oilpatch, not a "[[small-market]]" hockey team. With no single Albertan magnate willing to commit C$100 million to purchase the team, Nichols was forced to secure smaller investments from a larger number of investors. Lenders were willing to finance 40% of the purchase price, meaning Nichols needed to come up with about C$60 million. Nichols had about C$35 million in investments when an offer of US$85 million (C$120 million) came from a buyer who wanted to move the team to [[Houston]]. The Oilers' sale attracted interest in from several American cities, and as Nichols was securing local investors, an offer of US$85 million (C$120 million) came from [[Leslie Alexander (businessman)|Leslie Alexander]], a [[Houston]]-based businessman and an owner of the [[National Basketball Association]]'s [[Houston Rockets]]. Houston, who's application for an [[expansion team]] rejected by the league, was (and still is) the largest U.S. city without an NHL franchise. Alexander's original offer was to keep the team in Edmonton on the condition that the lease be terminated, attendance remained at acceptable levels, a local ownership group was eventually found and an expansion team be granted to Alexander in Houston. The [[Edmonton City Council]] rejected these terms, believing they gave Alexander too much discretion to move the Oilers to Texas. The city believed the lease they negotiated with Pocklington was still the best chance they had of keeping the team in Edmonton in the long term. Alexander then offered the ATB (which had the team in [[receivership]] by then) US$85 million (C$120 million) to purchase the team and move it to Houston, and submitted a US$5 million (C$7 million) [[deposit account|deposit]]. Nichols was given until March 13, 1998 to match the deposit and commit to purchasing the team for US$70 million (C$100 million), or the lease would be automatically terminated and the team would move. Nichols was eventually able to assemble a group of 38 local investors. As the deadline neared, the Edmonton Investors Group (EIG) decided to commit to the purchase by matching Alexander's deposit with a down payment of US$5 million (C$7 million). The remainder of the US$70 million (C$100 million) was paid to ATB 40 days later. On May 5, 1998, the NHL approved the sale and the EIG officially become the NHL owners. Although major sporting leagues generally frown upon large ownership groups controlling franchises, the NHL decided to forego putting a team in Houston and allow the Oilers' sale to EIG to proceed as they did not want to lose any more Canadian teams – this would have put their lucrative Canadian television contracts in jeopardy. The Edmonton Investors Group Ltd. is mainly a local ownership group, but includes a few business people from outside the city as well. The Oilers sale even drew interest from Calgary-born comic book creator [[Todd McFarlane]], creator of the famous [[Spawn (comics)|Spawn]] character. McFarlane and artist Brent Ashe later designed the Oilers’ third jersey. The Oilers' new owners have maintained good relations with fans. As a result, fans in Edmonton backed the league-imposed [[2004–05 NHL lockout|lockout]] of 2004–05, which wiped out an entire season, and came back after the lockout was settled. In the [[2005–06 NHL season]], the Oilers sold out every home game except one, where a computer glitch prevented the release of several hundred tickets. Following a successful 2005–06 season which saw the Oilers fall one win short of winning the [[Stanley Cup]] and a [[Alberta Advantage|boom in the Albertan economy]], fan support reached its highest levels. A waiting list for season ticket buyers, unheard of during the days of Pocklington's ownership, was put in place after the owners were compelled to cap the number of season tickets sold. The team has also announced that a [[lottery]] will be held for the right to purchase multi-game packages at Rexall Place. ==Daryl Katz purchase offers and sale== In the [[2006–07 NHL season]] the Oilers sold out every home game for the first time, despite missing the playoffs by a substantial margin. The ownership group then reportedly received a [[Canadian dollar|C$]]145 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|145000000|2007}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}) offer from local [[billionaire]] [[Daryl Katz]] for the franchise, although Nichols subsequently said the team was not for sale.{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/topics/sports/story.html?id=6bbf307d-d53b-4714-b248-292413dcf2cd&k=90929 |title=Oilers not for sale but bid to buy team won 'a lot of support' |author=MacKinnon, John |publisher=[[canada.com]] |date=2007-05-06 |accessdate=2008-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025033550/http://www.canada.com/topics/sports/story.html?id=6bbf307d-d53b-4714-b248-292413dcf2cd&k=90929 |archivedate=2012-10-25 |df= }} [[Daryl Katz]] upped the offer to C$150 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|150000000|2007}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}), but was turned down again. On August 7, [[Daryl Katz]] made a 3rd offer for the team of C$185 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|185000000|2007}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}). [[Cal Nichols]], spokesman for the EIG, said it amounted to a hostile takeover, and had caused divisions within the EIG. On December 13, 2007 [[Daryl Katz]] submitted a 4th formal offer to the EIG to buy the franchise. The offer was C$188 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|188000000|2007}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}) to the EIG shareholders, plus another $100 million towards the building of a new arena in downtown Edmonton, as well as a new state of the art training facility located at the [[University of Alberta]]. [[Cal Nichols]] indicated that he would accept the offer for his share of the team, but that the EIG had to have the owners of 2/3 of the shares agree to the proposal. [[Cal Nichols]] resigned as chairman of the board of directors for the EIG on December 14, 2007. Assuming the position of chairman of the board was Bill Butler, a minority shareholder & real estate developer.{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=3e57b7d4-6a7c-45e9-87ae-31583f265794 |title=Emergence of low-profile Edmonton developer '''Bill Butler''' creates online buzz among fans |publisher=[[Edmonton Journal]] |date=2008-01-09 |accessdate=2008-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103212917/http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=3e57b7d4-6a7c-45e9-87ae-31583f265794 |archivedate=2012-11-03 |df= }} The EIG met to decide on the bid January 21, 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.edmontonsun.com/News/Edmonton/2008/01/21/4785719.html |title=Daryl Katz absent, owners of Oilers weigh bid to buy team |publisher=[[Edmonton Sun]] |date=2008-01-21 |accessdate=2008-01-23 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Before the January 21st meeting there were rumours of a rival or plan B offer led by '''Gary Gregg''', '''Bill Butler''', '''Brian Nilsson''' and '''Jakob Ambrosius'''. These rumours were confirmed on January 23, as the rival faction would match the Katz offer either by soliciting new shareholders or taking a loan from Scotiabank using the hockey club as collateral.{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=4d282b56-cd9e-4124-8e58-5bc49e6f5464&k=53067 |title=Rivals 'matching' Katz's Oilers bid |author=Barnes, Dan |publisher=[[canada.com]] |date=2008-01-23 |accessdate=2008-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103212953/http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=4d282b56-cd9e-4124-8e58-5bc49e6f5464&k=53067 |archivedate=2012-11-03 |df= }} As reported on the [[Team 1260]] on January 24, 2008 as well as in the Edmonton Journal{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=6c39c032-99f1-4b4d-b7fb-58f8231f5567&k=28289 |title=Katz bid gaining support |author=Barnes, Dan |publisher=[[canada.com]] |date=2008-01-25 |accessdate=2008-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103214742/http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=6c39c032-99f1-4b4d-b7fb-58f8231f5567&k=28289 |archivedate=2012-11-03 |df= }} on January 25, 3 more directors of the Edmonton Investors Group stepped down. '''Ron Hodgson''', '''Neal Allen''' & '''Brian Hryniuk''' have resigned adding speculation that they may have accepted the Katz offer as well. The updated price per share is C$20,687 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|CA|20687|2008|r=0}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}) & sources close to [[Daryl Katz]] said he may be willing to close the deal only having 60% of the 7492 EIG shares. On June 18, 2008 it was reported that the sale of the Edmonton Oilers was approved{{cite web |url=http://www.faceoff.com/hockey/nhlnews/story.html?id=ebd24b4f-b687-4779-ba67-9ddb6fbb0fc6&add_feed_url=http%3a%2f%2fwww.faceoff.com%2ftopstories.atom |title=Oilers sale approved |author=Barnes, Dan |date=2008-06-18 |access-date=2008-06-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521004305/http://www.faceoff.com/hockey/nhlnews/story.html?id=ebd24b4f-b687-4779-ba67-9ddb6fbb0fc6&add_feed_url=http:%2f%2fwww.faceoff.com%2ftopstories.atom |archive-date=2011-05-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }} to [[Daryl Katz]] for a reported C$200 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|200000000|2008}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}). ==Shareholders== The ownership of the EIG was as follows (investors on the board of directors in '''BOLD'''):{{cite web | url=https://nationalpost.com/sports/story.html?id=251734 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20080208173756/http://www.nationalpost.com/sports/story.html?id=251734 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2008-02-08 | title=Oilers' owners warming to Katz's offer to buy team | author=Barnes, Dan | publisher=[[National Post]] | date=2008-01-20 | accessdate=2008-01-23 }} {| align=center border=1 cellspacing=1 cellpadding=4 style="border-collapse:collapse; text-align:center; line-height:normal" |- bgcolor=#eeeeee !Shareholder !Residence !Percentage Held |- |align="left"|'''Dave Addie''' || [[Lloydminster]] || 1.735% |- |align="left"|'''Neal Allen''' || [[Nisku]] |- |align="left"|'''Jakob Ambrosius''' || [[Edmonton]] |- |align="left"|Manuel Balsa || Edmonton |- |align="left"|Ted Barrett* || Los Angeles |- |align="left"|Edwin E. Bean || Edmonton || 8.00% |- |align="left"|Gordon Buchanan (1929–2014) || Edmonton |- |align="left"|'''Bill Butler''' || Edmonton |- |align="left"|Michael Dalton || [[Kelowna]] |- |align="left"|[[The Edmonton Journal]] || Edmonton |- |align="left"|Ernie Elko || Edmonton |- |align="left"|'''Gary Gregg''' || Edmonton || 9.14% |- |align="left"|Don Hamilton || Edmonton |- |align="left"|'''Ron Hodgson''' and [[Tom Mayson (Canadian football)|Tom Mayson]] (1928–2010) || Edmonton || 1.735% |- |align="left"|Jim Hole (1927–2018) || Edmonton || 9.14% |- |align="left"|'''Brian Hryniuk''' || Edmonton || 1.735% |- |align="left"|The Estate of Gerald Knoll (1932–2008){{cite web |url=http://oilers.nhl.com/team/app/?service=page&page=NewsPage&articleid=350467 |title=EIG Investor Gerald Knoll Passes Away |publisher=[[Edmonton Oilers hockey Club]] |date=2008-01-18 |accessdate=2008-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119214136/http://oilers.nhl.com/team/app/?service=page&page=NewsPage&articleid=350467 |archivedate=2008-01-19 |df= }} || Nisku || 1.67% |- |align="left"|'''Chris Kuchar'''** || Edmonton/Nisku |- |align="left"|Larry M. revision.text:
{{about|the film genre|films named "Epic"|Epic (disambiguation)}} [[File:Cabiria poster.jpg|thumb|Italian film ''[[Cabiria]]'' (1914), one of the earliest epic films and one of the most influential movies ever made]]
'''Epic films''' are a style of filmmaking with large scale, sweeping scope, and spectacle. The usage of the term has shifted over time, sometimes designating a film [[genre]] and at other times simply synonymous with big budget filmmaking. Like [[epic poetry|epics]] in the classical literary sense it is often focused on a [[hero|heroic character]]. An epic's ambitious nature helps to set it apart from other types of film such as the [[period piece]] or [[adventure film]].
Epic historical films would usually take a historical or a mythical event and add an extravagant setting and lavish costumes, accompanied by an expansive [[film score|musical score]] with an [[ensemble cast]], which would make them among the most expensive of films to produce. The most common subjects of epic films are royalty, and important figures from various periods in world history.<ref name="filmsite">{{cite news |last=Tim Dirks |title=Epic Films |publisher=Filmsite |date=12 July 2008 |url=http://www.filmsite.org/epicsfilms.html |accessdate=12 July 2008}}</ref>
==Characteristics== The term "epic" originally came from the poetic genre exemplified by such works as the ''[[Iliad]]'', ''[[Epic of Gilgamesh]]'', or the ''[[Odyssey]]''. In classical literature, epics are considered works focused on deeds or journeys of heroes upon which the fate of a large number of people depend. Similarly, films described as "epic" typically take a historical character, or a [[myth]]ic heroic figure. Common subjects of epics are [[Royal family|royalty]], [[gladiators]], great military leaders, or leading personalities from various periods in world history. However, there are some films described as "epic" almost solely on the basis of their enormous scope and the sweeping panorama of their settings such as ''[[How the West Was Won (film)|How the West Was Won]]'' or ''[[East of Eden (film)|East of Eden]]'' that do not have the typical substance of classical epics but are directed in an epic style.
When described as "epic" because of content, an epic movie is often set during a time of war or other societal crisis, while usually covering a longer span of time sometimes throughout entire generations coming and passing away, in terms of both the events depicted and the running time of the film. Such films usually have a historical setting, although [[fantasy]] or [[science fiction]] settings have become common in recent decades. The central conflict of the film is usually seen as having far-reaching effects, often changing the course of [[history]]. The main characters' actions are often central to the resolution of the societal conflict.
In its classification of films by genre, the [[American Film Institute]] limits the genre to historical films such as ''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]''. However, film scholars such as Constantine Santas are willing to extend the label to science-fiction films such as ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' and ''[[Star Wars]]''.<ref>{{cite book |title=Responding to film: a text guide for students of cinema art |last=Santas |first=Constantine |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2002 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |location= |isbn=978-0-8304-1580-9 |page=32 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> Lynn Ramey suggests that "Surely one of the hardest film genres to define is that of the "epic" film, encompassing such examples as ''Ben-Hur'', ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]''....and more recently, ''[[300 (film)|300]]'' and the ''[[Star Wars]]'' films...none of these comes from literary epics ''per se'', and there is little that links them with one another. Among those who espouse film genre studies, epic is one of the most despised and ignored genres"<ref>{{cite book |title=Hollywood in the Holy Land: essays on film depictions of the Crusades and Christian-Muslim clashes |last=Haydock |first=Nickolas |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2009 |publisher=McFarland |location= |isbn=978-0-7864-4156-3 |page=153 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> Finally, although the ''American Movie Channel'' formally defines epic films as historical films, they nonetheless state the epic film may be combined with the genre of science-fiction and cite ''Star Wars'' as an example.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmsite.org/epicsfilms.html |title=AMC Film Site Epics/Historical Films |publisher=Filmsite.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-16}}</ref>
Stylistically, films classed as epic usually employ spectacular settings and specially designed costumes, often accompanied by a sweeping musical score, and an [[ensemble cast]] of [[bankable star]]s. Epics are usually among the most expensive of films to produce. They often use on-location filming, authentic period [[costume]]s, and [[Action film|action]] scenes on a massive scale. [[Biographical film]]s may be less lavish versions of this genre.
Many writers may refer to any film that is "long" (over two hours) as an epic, making the definition epic a matter of dispute, and raise questions as to whether it is a "genre" at all. As [[Roger Ebert]] put it, in his "Great Movies" article on ''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]'':<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20010902%2FREVIEWS08%2F109020301%2F1023 |title=Lawrence of Arabia (1962) |accessdate=2007-06-18 |author=Roger Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |date=2001-09-02 |work=Great Movies |publisher=suntimes.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050904211006/http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20010902%2FREVIEWS08%2F109020301%2F1023 |archivedate=2005-09-04 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
{{quote|The word ''epic'' in recent years has become synonymous with ''big budget [[B-movie|B picture]].'' What you realize watching ''Lawrence of Arabia'' is that the word ''epic'' refers not to the cost or the elaborate production, but to the size of the ideas and vision. Werner Herzog's ''[[Aguirre: The Wrath of God]]'' didn't cost as much as the catering in ''[[Pearl Harbor (film)|Pearl Harbor]]'', but it is an epic, and ''Pearl Harbor'' is not.}}
The comedy film ''[[Monty Python and the Holy Grail]]'' had the joking [[tagline]] "Makes ''Ben-Hur'' look like an epic."
==History== The epic is among the oldest of film genres, with one early notable example being [[Giovanni Pastrone]]'s ''[[Cabiria]]'', a three-hour [[silent film]], about the [[Punic Wars]], that laid the groundwork for the subsequent silent epics of [[D. W. Griffith]].
The genre reached a peak of popularity in the early 1960s,<ref name="allmovie">{{cite news |last=allmovie |title=Explore by genre:Epic |publisher=allmovieg |date=2008-07-12 |url=http://www.allmovie.com/genre/epic-d657 |accessdate=2014-03-05}}</ref> when Hollywood frequently collaborated with foreign film studios (such as Rome's [[Cinecittà]]) to use relatively exotic locations in [[Spain]], [[Morocco]], and elsewhere for the production of epic films such as ''[[El Cid (film)|El Cid]]'' (1961) or ''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]'' (1962). This boom period of international co-productions is generally considered to have ended with ''[[Cleopatra (1963 film)|Cleopatra]]'' (1963), ''[[The Fall of the Roman Empire (film)|The Fall of the Roman Empire]]'' (1964), and ''[[Doctor Zhivago (film)|Doctor Zhivago]]'' (1965). Nevertheless, films in this genre continued to appear, with one notable example being ''[[War and Peace (film series)|War and Peace]]'', which was released in the former [[Soviet Union]] during 1967-1968 and, directed by [[Sergei Bondarchuk]], and said to be the most expensive film ever made.
Epic films continue to be produced, although since the development of CGI they typically use computer effects instead of an actual cast of thousands. Since the 1950s, such films have regularly been shot with a wide [[aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratio]] for a more immersive and panoramic theatrical experience.
Epic films were recognized in a montage at the [[78th Academy Awards|2006 Academy Awards]].
==Public reception==
===Gross revenue=== The enduring popularity of the epic is often accredited to their ability to appeal to a wide audience. Many of the [[List of highest-grossing films|highest-grossing films of all-time]] have been epics.<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/adjusted.htm |title=All Time Box Office Adjusted for Ticket Price Inflation |accessdate=2007-07-12 |author=Box Office Mojo |authorlink=Box Office Mojo |date= |work= |publisher=Box Office Mojo }}</ref> The 1997 film ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'', which is cited as helping to revive the genre, grossed $658 million domestically and over $2.1 billion worldwide, making it the second highest-grossing film of all-time behind the 2009 film ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'',<ref>[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/domestic.htm All Time Domestic Box Office Results<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> another epic which grossed $2.7 billion worldwide. If inflation is taken into account, then the historical epic ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' becomes the highest-grossing film ever in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/adjusted.htm |title=All Time Box Office Adjusted for Ticket Price Inflation |publisher=Boxofficemojo.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-16}}</ref> Adjusted for inflation it earned the equivalent of $1.6 billion in the United States alone.<ref name=BOM/> Adjusted for ticket price inflation, the science fiction/fantasy epic ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' stands at number 2, with an inflated gross of $1.4 billion in the United States.<ref name=BOM/>
===Academy Awards=== So far the most Academy Awards ever won by a single film stands at 11. This feat has only been achieved by 3 movies (''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]'', ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' and ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]'') all of which are considered epics.
==See also== *[[Historical fantasy]] *[[Historical fiction]] *[[Historical period drama]] *[[Sword and planet]] *[[Sword and sorcery]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * Constantine Santas, "The Epic in Film: From Myth to Blockbuster." Rowman & Littlefield, Lanham, Maryland: 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-7425-5528-0}}. * Constantine Santas, James M. Wilson, Maria Colavito, Djoymi Baker, "The Encyclopedia of Epic Films," Rowman & Littlefield, Lanham, Maryland: 2014. {{ISBN|978-0-8108-8247-8}}

{{refimprove|date=February 2008}} {{Infobox video game | image = Flatout2pc.jpg | caption = ''FlatOut 2'' European cover art | developer = [[Bugbear Entertainment]] | publisher = [[Empire Interactive]] | series = ''[[FlatOut]]'' | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]
[[macOS|OS X]]
[[PlayStation 2]]
[[Xbox (console)|Xbox]]
[[Linux]] | released = {{Video game release|EU|June 30, 2006|NA|August 1, 2006|WW|December 21, 2006 (Steam)}}'''OS X'''
{{vgrelease|NA|January 1, 2008}} | genre = [[Racing game|Racing]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | designer = }} '''''FlatOut 2''''' is a [[racing]] [[video game]] developed by [[Bugbear Entertainment]] and published by [[Empire Interactive]]. It is the sequel to the 2004 game ''[[FlatOut (video game)|FlatOut]]''. This game is themed more on the street racing/import tuner scene than its predecessor. A notable change is the tire grip; players can take more control of their car, worrying less about skidding in tight turns. The game has three car classes: derby, race, and street. It was released in Russia on June 29, 2006, in Europe on June 30, 2006, and in North America on August 1, 2006 In 2008, an OS X version of the game was released by [[Virtual Programming]] In 2014, a Linux version of the game was released on [[GOG.com]] as part of the launch of Linux support.{{cite web |url=http://www.gog.com/news/gogcom_now_supports_linux |title=GOG.com now supports Linux! |publisher=[[GOG.com]] |date=August 18, 2014}} ==Gameplay== ===Ragdoll physics=== The ragdoll physics in the sequel have been greatly updated. During the race, the driver may be thrown out of the car if slammed into a wall at a high speed. In the numerous [[Stunt]] [[minigames]] the goal is to shoot yourself out of the car and complete objectives like knocking down a set of [[bowling]] pins, hitting the designated spots on a [[dartboard]], score a [[Field goal (football)|field goal]] or fly through flaming hoops. Players must use '[[aerobatics]]' to control the driver in-flight, but overusing it will increase [[drag (physics)|drag]], which will slow the driver down and possibly prevent him/her from reaching the designated target. If the driver falls short of the target, players can use the "nudge". This gives the driver a small upward boost and slightly reduces drag. In the Stone Skipping Stunt minigame, the players must use nudge just as the driver hits the surface of the water to skip the most efficiently and reach the furthest. ==Remake== In 2008, the game was [[Video game remake|re-released]] for the [[Xbox 360]] and [[PlayStation Portable]] with additional features and a new soundtrack, under the new name ''[[FlatOut: Ultimate Carnage]]'' for the Xbox 360 and PC, and ''FlatOut: Head On'' for the PSP. {{clear}} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== {{Video game reviews | PC = true | PS2 = true | XBOX = true | na = true | Edge_PC = 6/10{{cite journal 73/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/flatout-2 |title=FlatOut 2 for PlayStation 2 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=July 12, 2015}} | MC_XBOX = 73/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox/flatout-2 |title=FlatOut 2 for Xbox Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=July 12, 2015}} }} The PC version of ''FlatOut 2'' received "generally favorable reviews", while the PlayStation 2 and Xbox versions received "average" reviews, according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]]. In Japan, ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave the PS2 version a score of all four sevens for a total of 28 out of 40. ===Awards=== * Won [[IGN]]'s award for Best [[PlayStation 2]] Racing Game of 2006.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} * Won ''[[X-Play]]''{{'}}s award for Best Racing Game of 2006.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.bugbear.fi/ Official Bugbear website] * {{moby game|id=/flatout-2}} {{FlatOut series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Flatout 2}} [[Category:2006 video games]] [[Category:FlatOut|*02]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in Finland]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox games]] [[Category:Lua-scripted video games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Vehicular combat games]] [[Category:Bugbear Entertainment games]] [[Category:Video games featuring protagonists of selectable gender]]

page.title: Global Recording Artist of the Year

revision.comment: /* Top 10 Global Recording Artists of the Year */ Fixed spelling of 'Global'
revision.text:
The '''Global Recording Artist of the Year''' is an award presented by the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]] (IFPI) to honor the most popular recording artist based on a total of [[album-equivalent unit]]s, which include [[music downloads]], [[streaming media|streaming]] and physical format sales.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.org/global-artist-chart.php|title=Global Artist Chart — IFPI — Representing the recording industry worldwide|website=www.ifpi.org|accessdate=4 December 2017}} It has been awarded every year since January 2014, with British boy band [[One Direction]] becoming the first act to receive the accolade for Global Recording Artist of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.org/news/One-Direction-are-officially-the-biggest-global-recording-artists-of-2013|title=One Direction are officially the biggest global recording artists of 2013|website=www.ifpi.org|accessdate=4 December 2017}} This success was attributed to the band's third studio album, ''[[Midnight Memories]]'', which became the best-selling album of the year with sales of four million copies worldwide.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/aug/01/one-direction-named-the-worlds-no-1-bestselling-artists|title=One Direction named the world's No 1 bestselling artists|first=Guardian|last=music|date=1 August 2014|publisher=|accessdate=4 December 2017|via=www.theguardian.com}} The music videos for its singles, "[[Best Song Ever]]" and "[[Story of My Life (One Direction song)|Story of My Life]]", had been watched almost 200 million and over 100 million times, respectively, on [[YouTube]] up to that point.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/earshot/one-direction-named-2013s-top-676027|title=One Direction Named 2013's Top Global Recording Artist|website=hollywoodreporter.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}} [[Taylor Swift]] was awarded the Global Recording Artist of 2014 after the commercial success of her fifth studio album, ''[[1989 (Taylor Swift album)|1989]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6480312/taylor-swift-named-ifpi-global-recording-artist-2014|title=Taylor Swift Named IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2014|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}} During the year, the album became the second global bestseller with sales of six million copies and spawned two international number-one singles, "[[Shake It Off]]" and "[[Blank Space]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-32315974|title=Digital music matches physical sales|date=15 April 2015|publisher=|accessdate=4 December 2017|via=www.bbc.com}} [[Adele]] received the award for the Global Recording Artist of 2015 with the release of her third studio album, ''[[25 (Adele album)|25]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6867321/adele-ifpi-global-recording-artist-2015|title=Adele Named IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2015|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}} It became the best-selling album of the year worldwide, selling 17.4 million copies. The album's lead single, "[[Hello (Adele song)|Hello]]" reached number one in nearly all countries where it charted, and became the seventh biggest digital song of the year with 12.3 million track-equivalent units.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-news/adeles-album-25-helped-reverse-two-decades-of-almost-uninterrupted-decline-in-music-industry-a3223361.html|title=Adele's 25 outsells the other top five bestsellers put together|website=standard.co.uk|accessdate=4 December 2017}} The Global Recording Artist of 2016 went to [[Drake (musician)|Drake]], whose fourth studio album, ''[[Views (album)|Views]]'', was the third best-selling album of the year with 2.3 million copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7685065/drake-ifpi-global-recording-artist-2016|title=Drake Named IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2016|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7775037/ifpi-beyonce-lemonade-highest-selling-album-2016-drake-song|title=Beyonce's 'Lemonade' Highest-Selling Album Globally in 2016; Drake Lands Top Song: IFPI|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017|date=25 April 2017}} ''View'' was more successful on streaming service, becoming the first album ever to accumulate one-billion streams on [[Apple Music]].{{cite news|last=Josephs|first=Brian|url=http://www.spin.com/2016/09/drakes-views-1-billion-apple-music/|title=Drake's Views Is The First Album To Earn 1 Billion Apple Music Streams {{!}} SPIN|date=2016-09-26|newspaper=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|accessdate=2016-10-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024023656/http://www.spin.com/2016/09/drakes-views-1-billion-apple-music/|archivedate=October 24, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The album's second single, "[[One Dance]]", which became the biggest digital song of the year, with 12.5 million track-equivalent units worldwide. [[Ed Sheeran]] received the award for the Global Recording Artist of 2017 with the release of his third studio album ''[[÷ (album)|÷]]'' (read as "divide") and its singles including "[[Shape of You]]", "[[Castle on the Hill]]", "[[Galway Girl (Ed Sheeran song)|Galway Girl]]" and "[[Perfect (Ed Sheeran song)|Perfect]]".{{cite news|title=Ed Sheeran officially named the best-selling global recording artist of 2017|url=http://www.ifpi.org/news/Ed-Sheeran-officially-named-the-best-selling-global-recording-artist-of-2017|accessdate=26 February 2018|agency=IFPI|date=26 February 2018}} He became the first IFPI Global Recording Artist of the Year to have both the best-selling album and single of the year. ==Top 10 Global Recording Artists of the Year== ===2013=== [[File:One Direction at the Logies Awards 2012.jpg|thumb|[[One Direction]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2013]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:70%" |- !Rank !Artist !IFPI Top 10 Album of the Year !IFPI Top 10 Single of the Year{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/music-sales-fail-to-go-in-one-direction-as-growth-turns-to-39-slide-9200304.html|title=Music sales fail to go in One Direction as growth turns to 3.9%|date=18 March 2014|website=independent.co.uk|accessdate=4 December 2017}} |- |1 !scope="row"|[[One Direction]] |''[[Midnight Memories]]'' (first) |{{n/a}} |- |2 !scope="row"|[[Eminem]] |''[[The Marshall Mathers LP2]]'' (second) |{{n/a}} |- |3 !scope="row"|[[Justin Timberlake]] |''[[The 20/20 Experience]]'' (third) |{{n/a}} |- |4 !scope="row"|[[Bruno Mars]] |''[[Unorthodox Jukebox]]'' (fourth) |"[[When I Was Your Man]]" (eighth) |- |5 !scope="row"|[[Katy Perry]] |''[[Prism (Katy Perry album)|Prism]]'' (sixth) |"[[Roar (song)|Roar]]" (fifth) |- |6 !scope="row"|[[Pink (singer)|Pink]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Just Give Me a Reason]]" (fourth) |- |7 !scope="row"|[[Macklemore & Ryan Lewis]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Thrift Shop]]" (second) |- |8 !scope="row"|[[Rihanna]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Stay (Rihanna song)|Stay]]" (tenth) |- |9 !scope="row"|[[Michael Bublé]] |''[[To Be Loved]]'' (seventh) |{{n/a}} |- |10 !scope="row"|[[Daft Punk]] |''[[Random Access Memories]]'' (fifth) |"[[Get Lucky (Daft Punk song)|Get Lucky]]" (sixth) |} ===2014=== [[File:Taylor Swift Red Tour 5, 2013.jpg|thumb|[[Taylor Swift]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2014]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:70%" |- !Rank !Artist !IFPI Top 10 Album of the Year !IFPI Top 10 Single of the Year |- |1 !scope="row"|[[Taylor Swift]] |''[[1989 (Taylor Swift album)|1989]]'' (second) |{{n/a}} |- |2 !scope="row"|[[One Direction]] |''[[Four (One Direction album)|Four]]'' (sixth) |{{n/a}} |- |3 !scope="row"|[[Ed Sheeran]] |''[[X (Ed Sheeran album)|X]]'' (third) |{{n/a}} |- |4 !scope="row"|[[Coldplay]] |''[[Ghost Stories (Coldplay album)|Ghost Stories]]'' (fourth) |{{n/a}} |- |5 !scope="row"|[[AC/DC]] |''[[Rock or Bust]]'' (seventh) |{{n/a}} |- |6 !scope="row"|[[Michael Jackson]] |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |- |7 !scope="row"|[[Pink Floyd]] |''[[The Endless River]]'' (ninth) |{{n/a}} |- |8 !scope="row"|[[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]] |''[[In The Lonely Hour]]'' (fifth) |{{n/a}} |- |9 !scope="row"|[[Katy Perry]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Dark Horse (Katy Perry song)|Dark Horse]]" (second) |- |10 !scope="row"|[[Beyoncé]] |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |- |} ===2015=== [[File:Adele 2016.jpg|thumb|[[Adele]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2015]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:70%" |- !Rank !Artist !IFPI Top 10 Album of the Year{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7326412/adele-wiz-khalifa-charlie-puth-ifpi-2015-global-albums-digital-songs|title=Adele, Wiz Khalifa and Charlie Puth Lead 2015 Global Albums and Digital Song Rankings|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}} !IFPI Top 10 Single of the Year |- |1 !scope="row"|[[Adele]] |''[[25 (Adele album)|25]]'' (first) |"[[Hello (Adele song)|Hello]]" (seventh) |- |2 !scope="row"|[[Ed Sheeran]] |''[[X (Ed Sheeran album)|X]]'' (second) |"[[Thinking Out Loud]]" (third) |- |3 !scope="row"|[[Taylor Swift]] |''[[1989 (Taylor Swift album)|1989]]'' (third) |"[[Blank Space]]" (eighth) |- |4 !scope="row"|[[Justin Bieber]] |''[[Purpose (Justin Bieber album)|Purpose]]'' (fourth) |{{n/a}} |- |5 !scope="row"|[[One Direction]] |''[[Made in the A.M.]]'' (sixth) |{{n/a}} |- |6 !scope="row"|[[Coldplay]] |''[[A Head Full Of Dreams]]'' (eighth) |{{n/a}} |- |7 !scope="row"|[[Maroon 5]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Sugar (Maroon 5 song)|Sugar]]" (fourth) |- |8 !scope="row"|[[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]] |''[[In The Lonely Hour]]'' (fifth) |{{n/a}} |- |9 !scope="row"|[[Drake (musician)|Drake]] |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |- |10 !scope="row"|[[The Weeknd]] |''[[Beauty Behind The Madness]]'' (tenth) |{{n/a}} |- |} ===2016=== [[File:Drake Bluesfest.jpg|thumb|upright=0.85|alt=A man wearing a blue sweater|[[Drake (musician)|Drake]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2016]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:70%" |- !Rank !Artist !IFPI Top 10 Album of the Year !IFPI Top 10 Single of the Year |- |1 !scope="row"|[[Drake (musician)|Drake]] |''[[Views (album)|Views]]'' (third) |"[[One Dance]]" (first) |- |2 !scope="row"|[[David Bowie]] |''[[Blackstar (album)|Blackstar]]'' (fifth) |{{n/a}} |- |3 !scope="row"|[[Coldplay]] |''[[A Head Full of Dreams]]'' (ninth) |{{n/a}} |- |4 !scope="row"|[[Adele]] |''[[25 (Adele album)|25]]'' (second) |{{n/a}} |- |5 !scope="row"|[[Justin Bieber]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Love Yourself (Justin Bieber song)|Love Yourself]]" (second)
"[[Sorry (Justin Bieber song)|Sorry]]" (fifth) |- |6 !scope="row"|[[Twenty One Pilots]] |''[[Blurryface]]'' (eighth) |"[[Stressed Out]]" (tenth) |- |7 !scope="row"|[[Beyoncé]] |''[[Lemonade (Beyoncé album)|Lemonade]]'' (first) |{{n/a}} |- |8 !scope="row"|[[Rihanna]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Work (Rihanna song)|Work]]" (sixth) |- |9 !scope="row"|[[Prince (musician)|Prince]] |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |- |10 !scope="row"|[[The Weeknd]] |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |- |} ===2017=== [[File:Ed Sheeran, V Festival 2014, Chelmsford (14788797777).jpg|thumb|right|[[Ed Sheeran]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2017]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:70%" |- !Rank !Artist !IFPI Top 10 Album of the Year{{citation|page=9|title= IFPI Global Music Report 2018 |publisher= International Federation of the Phonographic Industry |format= PDF |accessdate= 24 April 2018|url= http://www.ifpi.org/downloads/GMR2018.pdf}} !IFPI Top 10 Single of the Year |- |1 !scope="row"|[[Ed Sheeran]] |[[÷ (album)|'''''÷''''']] (first) |"[[Shape of You]]" (first)

{{Distinguish|Hyper (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox TV channel | name = Hyper | logofile = HYPER (new logo).png | logocaption = Hyper logo used since December 5, 2015 | logosize = 150px | launch = April 14, 2012 | slogan = | network = [[The 5 Network]]
[[Cignal|Cignal Digital TV]] | owner = [[MediaQuest Holdings|MediaQuest Holdings Inc.]]
([[TV5 Network|TV5 Network Inc.]]) | picture format = [[480i]] [[16:9]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]])
[[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | country = [[Philippines]] | broadcast area = Nationwide | headquarters = [[TV5 Media Center]], Reliance cor. Sheridan Sts., [[Mandaluyong|Mandaluyong City]], [[Philippines]] | sister names = [[Colours (TV channel)|Colours]]
[[One News (Philippines)|ONE News]]
[[Sari-Sari Channel]]
[[PBA Rush]] | web =http://cignal.tv | sat serv 1 = [[Cignal]] (Nationwide) | sat chan 1 = Channel 91 (SD)
Channel 261 (HD) | cable serv 1 = [[Cablelink]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 100 (SD) | cable serv 2 = Pioneer Cable Vision Inc. (PCVI)
([[Baybay City, Leyte]]) | cable chan 2 = Channel 48 (SD) |}} '''Hyper''' is a [[Philippines|Filipino]] sports and entertainment [[Satellite Television|satellite]] and [[Cable Television|cable television channel]] based in [[Mandaluyong|Mandaluyong City]]. It is owned and operated by [[MediaQuest Holdings, Inc.]], a wholly owned subsidiary of the [[PLDT|PLDT Beneficial Trust Fund]] through [[The 5 Network]] and [[ESPN 5]].[http://www.interaksyon.com/infotech/cignal-forges-on-with-the-most-hd-channels-nationwide-launches-original-premium-offerings Cignal forges on with the most HD channels nationwide, launches original premium offerings] retrieved via www.interaksyon.com 03-30-2012 [http://www.interaksyon.com/article/26365/oli-pettigrew-looking-to-connect-with-more-filipino-fans Oli Pettigrew looking to connect with more Filipino fans] retrieved via www.interaksyon.com 03-08-2012 ==Channel Information== Hyper was on test broadcast on [[Cignal|Cignal Digital TV]] channel 43 from April 7 to 13, 2012, together with [[Colours (TV channel)|Colours]] as of this time. Full channel launch on April 14, 2012, and it is now on channel 53 via [[Cignal|Cignal Digital TV]]. Hyper also aired entertainment programming and other local sports from San Lazaro Broadcasting Network until December 4th, 2015 when SLBN moved to its newly launched Gametime TV on December 5, 2015 and can now be seen on Cignal Channel 109. In 2016, Hyper started airing [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] matches after [[ESPN 5]] acquired the broadcast rights of the UFC from [[ABS-CBN Sports]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.ph/combat-sports/news/ufc-on-sports5-cignal-abs-cbn-balls-skycable-destiny-cable|title=TV5 gets rights to air UFC fights as Balls Channel announces it is going off the air|publisher=Spin.ph|date=21 December 2015|accessdate=21 December 2015}} On January 8, 2016, Hyper relaunched its HD simulcast dubbed as '''Hyper HD''' which it can be seen on Cignal Channel 130. Effective December 19, 2016, Hyper will have new channel assignments on Cignal, which is on Channel 91 (SD) and on Channel 261 (HD). ==Programming== Note: Programs that are also aired on TV5 or AksyonTV are marked with asterisks. * FIBA 3X3* * [[National Football League]]* * [[PBA Developmental League]]* * [[PGA Tour]] * [[Philippine Super Liga]]* * [[Sports 360]]* * Standard Chartered Marathon * [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]]* ==AKTV== {{main|AKTV}} '''[[AKTV]]''', [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]]'s former primetime sports and active lifestyle programming arm, AKTV has a block time contract with [[Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation|IBC]] that gives it the primetime slot from 5-11 pm on weekdays and 11:00 am to 11:00 pm on weekends in the government sequestered network, it was announced that [[MediaQuest Holdings]]/TV5 chairman [[Manuel V. Pangilinan]] due to expiration contract between AKTV and IBC expires in May 2013. The development is not expected to affect the [[PBA Commissioner's Cup|Commissioner’s Cup]] coverage since the tournament would be over by the time the [[AKTV]]-[[Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation|IBC]] deal expires, but the board will have to sit down again soon to discuss on which free television channel the [[Philippine Basketball Association|PBA]] games will be aired next. With [[Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation|IBC-13]] being eyed for [[privatization]] by the government, the station can no longer agree to any long-term contract with blocktimers due to high costs and poor ratings, while [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]] is currently loaded with programing during its primetime slot, including an hour-long newscast. ==See also== *[[AKTV]] *[[ESPN 5]] *[[PBA Rush]] *[[The 5 Network]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{TV5}} {{Philippine cable channels}} [[Category:TV5 Network]] [[Category:Television in the Philippines]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2012]] [[Category:Philippine television networks]] [[Category:Sports television networks in the Philippines]]

{{Infobox video game | title = J.U.L.I.A. Among the Stars | image= Juliaatsboxart.jpg | developer = [[CBE Software]] | publisher = | modes = [[Single-player]] | designer = | writer = | programmer = | composer = | engine = | platforms = [[Windows]], [[OS X]], [[Linux]] | released = 12 October 2014 | genre = [[Adventure game]], [[puzzle video game]] }} '''''J.U.L.I.A. Among the Stars''''' is a 2014 [[video game]] by CBE Software. It is a [[Video game remake|remake]] of ''[[J.U.L.I.A.]]'', featuring improved graphics, a different gameplay and an expanded story.<ref name=AG>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Katie|title=J.U.L.I.A. Among the Stars review|url=http://www.adventuregamers.com/articles/view/27375 |website=Adventure Gamers |accessdate=10 October 2014}}</ref>
==Gameplay== J.U.L.I.A. is an interfaced based [[point and click adventure]] game. Throughout the game the player controls various computer interfaces and a reconnaissance robot for planetary exploration.
== Plot == In 2430, the expedition was sent to a distant star system. Rachel Manners, an astrobiologist who is part of the expedition, is awakened from cryogenic sleep by the ship's artificially intelligent computer J.U.L.I.A. when the ship is damaged by asteroids. It is revealed that all other members of the expedition were awakened 60 years ago and died due to unknown circumstances.
Rachel and J.U.L.I.A. start to investigate what happened. The exploration of planets is provided by MOBOT, an exploration lunar robot. They reveal that before all incidents that killed the crew happened, there was an incident during which the crew attacked an inhabited planet, Ambrosia, that suffers from a poisoned lake that kills their planet. The crew then decided to cover up the incident by destroying Ambrosians with advanced weapon. Rachel is shocked by this fact. They eventually find a temple where they meet a member of a race of stone-like beings that oversees balance in the universe. They are told about a race of Ancients that humiliated Ambrosians for their advanced culture and destroyed their home world before exiling them to Ambrosia. Ancients then poisoned the lake on Ambrosia, which kills the environment.
Rachel, MOBOT and J.U.L.I.A. are tasked with defeating Xir, a monster on planet Xenophon. The decide to use the weapon originally supposed to cover up the crew's failure. MOBOT eventually meets Xir and is attacked by him but MOBOT avoids Xir. Xir is destroyed in the end by the weapon and is revealed to be a weapon. Rachel then finds a new planet. It was a home world of Ancients before stone-like beings destroyed them. Rachel finds out that the crew was killed by J.U.L.I.A. who tried to protect Ambrosians. She is shocked but in the end she reconciles with this fact. They also find a way to help Ambrosians but they need to use resources necessary to get home.
If player decides to get back on Earth J.U.L.I.A. puts Rachel to cryogenic sleep and departs to Earth. If player decides to help the Ambrosians, the lake is purified and Rachel wants to live with Ambrosians but MOBOT and J.U.L.I.A. reveal that she would be slain by them. They depart for new adventures. The game ends with Rachel doing some job as a stone-like creature is shown to watch her. After the final credits, MOBOT is seen enjoying his time on a Planet Zenobia.
==Development== The original game was released in 2012 by Lace Mamba. It gained mixed reviews from players and CBE Software got into trouble as the publisher didn't pay the amount prescribed by the contract. It got CBE Software into financial trouble that the company eventually handled by launching an [[Indiegogo]] campaign for the Enhanced Edition of ''[[J.U.L.I.A.]]''. The required amount was $5,000 but developers raised $14,200 and the game was also Greenlighted for [[Steam (software)|Steam]] release. The project eventually transformed into a full-fledged remake and was released in October 2014.<ref name=jkavan>{{cite web|last1=Böke|first1=Ingmar|title=Jan Kavan - J.U.L.I.A. Enhanced Edition interview|url=http://www.adventuregamers.com/articles/view/24318|website=Adventure Gamers|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=vyvoj>{{cite web|last1=Bach|first1=Martin|title=Vývoj her v Česku v roce 2013 - část 1. |url=http://games.tiscali.cz/tema/vyvoj-her-v-cesku-v-roce-2013-cast-1-65583 |website=Games.cz|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref>
The game was also sold directly by the developers via their own [[DRM-free]] webshop, additionally to [[gog.com]].<ref>[http://store.cbe-software.com/index.php CBE software DRM free store] on cbe-software</ref> They had to stop direct sale due to a changed [[EU VAT]] legislation in 2015.
==Reception== {{expand section|date=February 2015}} The game has been well received by critics.<ref>[https://www.keengamer.com/article/12101_julia-among-the-stars-review julia-among-the-stars-review] on keengamer.com</ref><ref>[https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/tag/j-u-l-i-a-among-the-stars/ j-u-l-i-a-among-the-stars] on [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]</ref> The average score is 77.65% while median is 80%. It also holds 70% on [[Metacritic]] (based on 8 reviews).<ref name=siterev>{{cite web|title=All Reviews|url=http://www.juliathegame.com/all-reviews/|website=J.U.L.I.A.: Among the Stars|accessdate=10 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=MC>{{cite web|title=J.U.L.I.A.: Among the Stars PC|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/julia-among-the-stars|website=Metacritic|accessdate=10 October 2014}}</ref>
The game has received a Silver Aggie Award for the Best Update/Remake.<ref name=agg>{{cite web|title=The Aggie Awards - The Best Adventure Games of 2014|url=http://www.adventuregamers.com/articles/view/28100/page14|website=Adventure Gamers |accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
